question: Fill in the blank with the correct article: Socrates was _________ wisest of Greek philosophers.
description: -‘The’ is used before definite nouns, superlative degree adjectives, ordinal numbers and physical positions.

question: Fill in the blanks with the correct articles: Add _______ vowel after _______ last consonant.
description:
-Article ‘a’ is used with singular countable noun which is pronounced with consonant sound.
-Definite article ‘the’ is used before ordinal numbers like first, second, third and last etc.

question: Fill in the blank with the correct article: I have never seen such _______ beautiful picture.
description:
-Such/As/Many/Quite/Rather + a/an + Adjective + Singular Countable Noun
-A – used for consonant sound.
-An – used for vowel sound.

question: Fill in the blank with the correct article: _______ Elephants are intelligent animals.
description: -Article is omitted before possessive adjectives, comparative degree adjectives, abstract nouns, plural nouns, uncountable nouns, material nouns, proper nouns etc.

question: Fill in the blanks with the correct articles: Mangoes are sold by __________ kilo, eggs by __________ dozen.
description:
-‘The’ article is used before quantity that is used to show measurement.
-By + the + dozen/ litre/ meter/ kilo/ quintal/ barrel/ kilometer/ kilogram

question: Fill in the blank with the correct article: _________ Virtue is a behaviour which shows high moral standards.
description: -Article is omitted before possessive adjectives, comparative degree adjectives, abstract nouns, plural nouns, uncountable nouns, material nouns, proper nouns etc.

question: Fill in the blanks with the correct articles: I had ________ unique opportunity to strike ________ unexpected blow.
description:
-A/An + Adjective + Singular Countable Noun
-A – used for consonant sound.
-An – used for vowel sound.

question: Fill in the blank with the correct article: He works in ________ L.I.C. of India.
description: -‘The’ is used before definite nouns, superlative degree adjectives, ordinal numbers and physical positions.

question: Fill in the blank with the correct article: _______ deaf don’t hear Bible verse.
description:
-‘The’ is used before a noun which indicates the whole class or category of people, animals or things.
-The deaf – deaf people

question: Fill in the blank with the correct article: Look at ________ apples on that tree. These are very large.
description: -‘The’ is used before definite nouns, decades, superlative degree adjectives, ordinal numbers and physical positions like; top, bottom, back, front, centre etc.

question: Fill in the blank with the correct article: You always seem to be in ________ hurry.
description: -In some special phrases, ‘A/An’ is used, like in a fix, in a hurry, in a jiffy, make a noise, in a way, make a foot, a matter of chance, at a stone’s throw, at a discount, have a good education, at a loss, take a fancy to, take an interest in, to have a drink, a short while ago, half a kilo, keep a secret, as a rule, put an end etc.

question: Fill in the blanks with the correct articles: Bangalore is ________ Silicon Valley of ________ India.
description:
-If one proper noun is compared to another proper noun in a sentence, article ‘The’ is used before proper noun.
-Article is omitted before the name of streets, parks, cities, states, countries, continents, single lakes, single mountain peaks, subjects, languages, meals, sports, relations, diseases, festivals, days, months, seasons, colours etc.

question: Fill in the blank with the correct article: If you go to Agra, You must see _____ Taj Mahal.
description: -‘The’ is used before the name of body parts, designation, holy books, magazines, communities, historical buildings, historical events, movements, dynasties, forts, monuments, political parties, heavenly bodies, mountain ranges, rivers, oceans, seas, gulfs, canals, united countries, group of islands, group of lakes, directions etc.

question: Fill in the blank with the correct article: Men fear ________ death.
description: -No Article is used when Common Noun (man, woman, life, death, science, art, nature etc.) used in widest sense. (व्यापक अर्थ)

question: Fill in the blanks with the correct articles: _______ more you earn, _______ more you spend.
description: -When comparative degree is used in parallel expressions, we use article ‘The’ before both the adjectives.

question: Fill in the blank with the correct article: __________Yamuna is a holy river.
description: -‘The’ is used before the name of body parts, designation, holy books, magazines, communities, historical buildings, historical events, movements, dynasties, forts, monuments, political parties, heavenly bodies, mountain ranges, rivers, oceans, seas, gulfs, canals, united countries, group of islands, group of lakes, directions etc.

question: Fill in the blanks with the correct articles: ______ Ramayana is the story of ______ Lord Rama.
description:
-‘The’ is used before the name of body parts, post, position, designation, holy books, musical instruments, historical buildings, historical events, forts, monuments, museums, epics, heavenly bodies, mountain ranges, rivers, group of islands, group of lakes, directions etc.
-Article is omitted before possessive adjectives, comparative degree adjectives, abstract nouns, plural nouns, uncountable nouns, material nouns, proper nouns etc.

question: Fill in the blank with the correct article: This city has _____ ideal climate.
description:
-A/An + Adjective + Singular Countable Noun
-A – used for consonant sound.
-An – used for vowel sound.

question: Fill in the blanks with the correct articles: _______ Wisdom is not the same thing as _______ Knowledge.
description: -Article is omitted before possessive adjectives, comparative degree adjectives, abstract nouns, plural nouns, uncountable nouns, material nouns, proper nouns etc.

question: Fill in the blanks with the correct articles: My friend bought _____ orange and I bought _____ apple. Then we sat down to eat _____ fruits.
description:
-‘A/An’ is used before singular countable nouns to indicate number one, per, each etc.
-A – used for consonant sound.
-An – used for vowel sound.
-‘The’ is used before definite nouns, decades, superlative degree adjectives, ordinal numbers and physical positions like; top, bottom, back, front, centre etc.

question: Fill in the blank with the correct form of tense: It's time we ____________ (leave).
description:
-It is time + to + V1
-It is time/It is high time/It is about time + Sub. + V2
-It was time/It was high time/It was about time + Sub. + had + V3

question: Fill in the blank with the correct form of tense: She always _________ (carry) an umbrella.
description:
-'Simple Present Tense' is used to express general truth, habitual activities, universal truth, scientific truth, mathematical truth etc.
-Adverbials: Often, usually, sometimes, once a week/year/month/day, generally, regularly, always, frequently, seldom, usually, everyday, daily etc.
-Affirmative: Sub. + V1/V5(s/es) + Obj.
-Negative: Sub. + do/does + not + V1 + Obj.

question: Fill in the blanks with the correct form of tense: I ________ already _________ (have) my breakfast.
description:
-Present Perfect Tense – used to denote an action in the past with a result now. It expresses a finished action.
-Sub. + has/have + V3 + Obj.

question: Fill in the blanks with the correct form of tense: _________ they not ___________ (study) English these days?
description:
-‘Present Continuous Tense’ is used to show continuous activity.
-Adverbials – at this time, now, right now, at this moment, day by day, these days, now a days, look, incessantly etc.
-Affirmative: Sub. + is/am/are + V1 + ing + Obj.
-Negative: Sub. + is/am/are + not + V1 + ing + Obj.
-Interrogative: Is/Am/Are + Sub. + V1 + ing + Obj.?
-Interrogative-Negative: Is/Am/Are/ + Sub. + not + V1 + ing + Obj.?

question: Fill in the blank with the correct form of tense: By the next year, I ______________________ (work) hard to achieve my goal for five years.
description:
-‘By + future time ……….. since/for + time’ format is used in ‘Future Perfect Continuous Tense’.
-Sub. + will/shall + have + been + V1 + ing + Obj. + since/for + time
-Since – used to denote point of time.
-For – used to denote period of time.

question: Fill in the blank with the correct form of tense: I _______________________ (work) for two hours.
description:
-Present Perfect Continuous Tense:
-Sub. + has/have + been + V1 + ing + Obj. + since/for + time
-Since – used to denote point of time.
-For – used to denote period of time.

question: Fill in the blank with the correct form of tense: Generally, honesty ___________ (come) from the heart.
description:
-’Simple Present Tense’ is used to denote scientific or general truth.
-Affirmative: Sub. + V1/V5(s/es) + Obj.
-Negative: Sub. + do/does + not + V1 + Obj.

question: Fill in the blanks with the correct form of tense: It is still __________ (rain) but it _______ (look) as if it will soon stop.
description:
-‘Like, know, admire, trust, look, forget, smell, see, feel, taste, seem, hear, want, understand, love, hate’ are non-continuous verbs, these verbs are not used in continuous tenses.
Note: If the verb is NCV, we should use the ‘Simple Present Tense’ in place of the ‘Present Continuous Tense’.
-Simple Present Tense:
-Affirmative: Sub. + V1/V5(s/es) + Obj.
-Negative: Sub. + do/does + not + V1 + Obj.
-Present Continuous Tense:
-Sub. + is/are/am + V1 + ing + Obj.

question: Fill in the blank with the correct form of tense: Viren entered the classroom and __________ (begin) to speak.
description:
-Simple Past Tense – used for two different works which begin and end at the same time in past.
-Sub. + V2 + Obj.

question: Fill in the blank with the correct form of tense: She _________________ (sing) songs at this time tomorrow.
description:
-Future Continuous Tense:
-Adverbial: at this time + future time expression
-Sub. + shall/will + be + V1 + ing + Obj. + future time expression

question: Fill in the blank with the correct form of tense: As soon as she ______________ (finish) the book, she informed the publisher.
description: -When two actions happened in the past simultaneously, one action happened following the other, ‘Past Perfect Tense (had + V3)’ is used with the first action and ‘Simple Past Tense (V2)’ is used with the second action.

question: Fill in the blank with the correct form of tense: He ______________ (own) this car for ten years.
description:
-‘Like, know, own, admire, trust, look, forget, smell, see, need, feel, taste, seem, hear, want, understand, love, hate’ are non-continuous verbs, these verbs are not used in continuous tenses.
Note: If the verb is NCV, we should use the ‘Present Perfect Tense (has/have + V3)’ in place of the ‘Continuous Tenses’.

question: Fill in the blanks with the correct form of tense: When I arrived at the party, Jaya _______ already __________ (go) home.
description: -When two actions happened in the past simultaneously, one action happened following the other, ‘Past Perfect Tense (had + V3)’ is used with the first action and ‘Simple Past Tense (V2)’ is used with the second action.

question: Fill in the blank with the correct form of tense: My brother _______________ (drink) a glass of milk two hours ago.
description:
-Simple Past Tense – used to express things that happened in the past and has no connection with the present, shows completion of the action.
-Adverbials: yesterday, last year, last week, last month, last night, past + time expression, childhood, ago, in + past time expression etc.
-Sub. + V2 + Obj. + extra elements

question: Fill in the blanks with the correct form of tense: I ______ not _______ (go) to his house yesterday.
description:
-Simple Past Tense – used to express things that happened in the past and has no connection with the present, shows completion of the action.
-Adverbials: yesterday, last year, last week, last month, last night, past + time expression, childhood, ago, in + past time expression etc.
-Simple Past Tense:
-Affirmative: Sub. + V2 + Obj. + extra elements
-Negative: Sub. + did + not + V1 + Obj. + extra elements

question: Fill in the blank with the correct form of tense: Anita _________________ (teach) for twelve years when I joined the school.
description:
-Past Perfect Continuous Tense + when + Simple Past Tense:
-Sub. + had + been + V1 + ing + Obj. + for/since + time + when + Sub. + V2 + Obj.
-Since – used to denote point of time.
-For – used to denote period of time.

question: Fill in the blank with the correct form of tense: Honey reached the school after the bell ______________ (ring).
description:
-When two actions happened in the past simultaneously, one action happened following the other, ‘Past Perfect Tense’ is used with the first action and ‘Simple Past Tense’ is used with the second action.
-Sub. + V2 + Obj. + after + Sub. + had + V3 + Obj.
-Sub. + had + V3 + Obj. + before + Sub. + V2 + Obj.

question: Fill in the blank with the correct form of tense: I'm sure I ___________ (see) them at the party last night.
description:
-Simple Past Tense – used to express things that happened in the past and has no connection with the present, shows completion of the action.
-Adverbials: yesterday, last year, last week, last month, last night, past + time expression, ago, in + past time expression etc.
-Sub. + V2 + Obj.

question: Fill in the blank with the correct form of tense: While I _____________ (wait) for you, I fell asleep.
description: -'Past Continuous Tense (was/were + V1 + ing)' indicates an action going on at some time in the past or an action in the past that is longer in duration than another action is used in 'Simple Past Tense (V2)'.

question: Fill in the blank with the correct form of tense: It was time we _____________ (start) working.
description:
-It is time + to + V1
-It is time/It is high time/It is about time + Sub. + V2
-It was time/It was high time/It was about time + Sub. + had + V3

question: Transform the given sentence into passive voice: The interviewer asked me my name.
option_1: The interviewer had been asked my name by me.
option_2: I was asked my name by the interviewer.
option_3: I had been asked my name by the interviewer.
option_4: I have been asked my name by the interviewer.
description:
-Simple Past Tense:
-Active Voice – Sub. + V2 + IO + DO
-Passive Voice – IO + was/were + V3 + DO + by agent
or
-DO + was/were + V3 + Preposition + IO + by agent
eg. My name was asked to me by the interviewer.
-IO – Indirect Object
-DO – Direct Object

question: Transform the given sentence into active voice: The Metro Train is being constructed by the Corporation.
option_1: The Corporation is constructing the Metro Train.
option_2: The Corporation is constructed the Metro Train.
option_3: The Corporation is being constructing the Metro Train.
option_4: The Corporation is being constructed the Metro Train.
description:
-Present Continuous Tense:
-Active Voice – Sub. + is/are/am + V1 + ing + Obj.
-Passive Voice – Obj. + is/are/am + being + V3 + by agent

question: Transform the given sentence into passive voice: Our team may win the match.
option_1: Our team may be won the match.
option_2: The match might be won by our team.
option_3: Our team might be won the match.
option_4: The match may be won by our team.
description:
-Use of ‘Modal’:
-Active Voice – Sub. + Modal + V1 + Obj.
-Passive Voice – Obj. + Modal + be + V3 + by agent

question: Transform the given sentence into passive voice: Why had you not deposited the school fees?
option_1: Why had the school fees not been deposited by you?
option_2: Why the school fees had not been deposited by you?
option_3: Why had the school fees not deposited by you?
option_4: Why the school fees had been not deposited by you?
description:
-Past Perfect Tense: (Interrogative-Negative)
-Active Voice – W/H word + had + Sub. + not + V3 + Obj.?
-Passive Voice – W/H word + had + Obj. + not + been + V3 + by agent?

question: Transform the given sentence into passive voice: Start the work immediately.
option_2: You are ordered to start the work immediately.
option_4: The work should have started immediately.
description:
-Imperative Sentence:
-Active Voice – V1 + Obj. + extra elements
-Passive Voice – You are ordered/ requested/ advised/ asked/ suggested + to + V1 + Obj. + extra elements
or
-Let + Obj. + be + V3 + extra elements
eg. Let the work be started immediately.

question: Transform the given sentence into passive voice: Why didn’t you bring the matter to my notice?
option_1: Why wasn’t the matter brought to my notice?
option_2: Why isn’t the matter brought by you to my notice?
option_3: Why isn’t being the matter brought to my notice?
option_4: Why wasn’t being the matter brought by you to my notice?
description:
-Simple Past Tense: (Interrogative-Negative)
Active Voice – W/H word + didn’t + Sub. + V1 + Obj. + extra elements?
Passive Voice – W/H word + was/were + Obj. + not + V3 + by agent + extra elements?
Note: ‘Agent’ is omitted when it is understood, like ‘No one, Nobody, Nothing, Someone, Somebody, Something, Police, We, They, One, Everyone, Everybody, Everything, People’ etc.

question: Transform the given sentence into active voice: Your kindness will never be forgotten by me.
option_1: I shall never forget your kindness.
option_2: I shall never be forgotten your kindness.
option_3: Your kindness will never forget to me.
option_4: I will never be forgotten your kindness.
description:
-Simple Future Tense:
-Active Voice – Sub. + will/shall + V1 + Obj.
-Passive Voice – Obj. + will/shall + be + V3 + by agent

question: Transform the given sentence into passive voice: Sita is singing a beautiful song.
option_1: A song has been beautifully sung by Sita.
option_2: A beautiful song has been sung by Sita.
option_3: A beautiful song is being sung by Sita.
option_4: A song is sung by beautiful Sita.
description:
-Present Continuous Tense:
-Active Voice – Sub. + is/are/am + V1 + ing + Obj.
-Passive Voice – Obj. + is/are/am + being + V3 + by agent

question: Transform the given sentence into passive voice: Does he pluck leaves?
description:
-Simple Present Tense: (Interrogative)
Active Voice – Do/Does + Sub. + V1 + Obj. + extra elements?
Passive Voice – Is/Am/Are + Obj. + V3 + by agent + extra elements?

question: Transform the given sentence into passive voice: The list includes his name.
option_1: The list is to include his name.
option_2: His name is included with the list.
option_3: His name is included in the list.
option_4: The list is included by his name.
description:
-Simple Present Tense:
-Active Voice – Obj.1 + V1/V5(s/es) + Obj.2
-Passive Voice – Obj.2 + is/are/am + V3 + Preposition (in) + Obj.1
Note: Verbs with ‘Fixed preposition’:- Known to, amazed at, alarmed at, annoyed with, surprised at, shocked at, contained in, held in, included in, pleased with, decorated with, engulfed in, satisfied with, disgusted with, impressed with, offended with, lined with etc.

question: Transform the given sentence into passive voice: Who can solve this question?
option_1: By whom can this question be solved?
option_2: Who can be solved this question?
option_3: By whom could this question be solve?
option_4: Who could be solved this question?
description:
-Use of ‘Modal’: (Interrogative)
-Active Voice – Who + Modal + V1 + Obj.?
-Passive Voice – By whom + Modal + Obj. + be + V3?

question: Transform the given sentence into passive voice: It is time to revise the old banking regulations.
option_1: It is time for the old banking regulations to be revised.
option_2: It is time for the old banking regulations be revised.
option_3: The old banking regulations should be revised.
option_4: It is time for the old banking regulations should revised.
description:
-Active Voice – It is time + to + V1 + Obj.
-Passive Voice – It is time + for + Obj. + to + be + V3

question: Transform the given sentence into passive voice: Nobody objected to the idea.
option_1: The idea not was objected by anybody.
option_2: The idea was not objected to.
option_3: Nobody was objected to the idea.
option_4: The idea was not objected to by nobody.
description:
-Simple Past Tense
-Active Voice – Sub. + V2 + Obj.
-Passive Voice – Obj. + was/were + V3 + by agent
Note: ‘Agent’ is omitted when it is understood, like ‘No one, Nobody, Someone, Somebody, Nothing, Something, Police, We, They, One, Everyone, Everybody, Everything, People’ etc.
-If the subject is ‘Nobody/No one’, the sentence will be negative in passive voice.

question: Transform the given sentence into passive voice: I have completed my homework.
option_1: My homework has completed by me.
option_2: My homework has been completed by me.
option_3: My homework had been completed by me.
option_4: My homework has been completing by me.
description:
-Present Perfect Tense:
-Active Voice – Sub. + has/have + V3 + Obj.
-Passive Voice – Obj. + has/have + been + V3 + by agent

question: Transform the given sentence into active voice: The teacher was pleased with the boy’s work.
option_1: The boy’s work pleased the teacher.
option_2: The boy’s work was pleased the teacher.
option_3: The boy’s work please the teacher.
option_4: The boy’s work has pleased the teacher.
description:
-Simple Past Tense:
-Active Voice – Obj.1 + V2 + Obj.2
-Passive Voice – Obj.2 + was/were + V3 + Preposition (with) + Obj.1
Note: Verbs with ‘Fixed preposition’:- Known to, amazed at, alarmed at, annoyed with, surprised at, shocked at, contained in, held in, included in, pleased with, decorated with, engulfed in, satisfied with, disgusted with, impressed with, offended with etc.

question: Transform the given sentence into passive voice: They will have to do the work sincerely.
option_1: Sincerely the work will be done by them.
option_2: The work has been done by them sincerely.
option_3: The work will have to be done sincerely by them.
option_4: The work will have been done sincerely by them.
description:
-Active Voice – to + V1
-Passive Voice – to + be + V3

question: Transform the given sentence into passive voice: May you achieve success in all your endeavours.
option_1: Success might be achieved by you in all your endeavours.
option_2: May success be achieved by you in all your endeavours.
option_3: May success will be achieved by you in all your endeavours.
option_4: Success has been achieved by you in all your endeavours.
description:
-Optative Sentence:
-Active Voice – May + Sub. + V1 + Obj. + extra elements
-Passive Voice – May + Obj. + be + V3 + by agent + extra elements

question: Transform the given sentence into passive voice: They say that people live on distant planets.
option_1: It is said that people lives on distant planets.
option_2: It is being said that people live on distant planets.
option_3: It is said that people live on distant planets.
option_4: It is saying that people live on distant planets.
description:
-If a sentence starts with ‘They say’:
-Active Voice – They say + that + ………
-Passive Voice – It is said + that + ……….

question: Transform the given sentence into active voice: The traitors should be shot dead by them.
option_1: They should have shot the traitors dead.
option_2: They shall be shot the traitors dead.
option_3: They should shoot the traitors dead.
option_4: They should have been shot the traitors dead.
description:
-Use of ‘Modal’:
-Active Voice – Sub. + Modal + V1 + Obj.
-Passive Voice – Obj. + Modal + be + V3 + by agent

question: Transform the given sentence into active voice: Is a dress being selected by her?
option_3: Is she being selected a dress?
option_4: Does she is selecting a dress?
description:
-Present Continuous Tense: (Interrogative)
-Active Voice – Is/Are/Am + Sub. + V1 + ing + Obj.?
-Passive Voice – Is/Are/Am + Obj. + being + V3 + by agent?

question: Choose the correct indirect speech of the given sentence from the options that follow: He said to me, “How is your mother?”
option_1: He asked me how was my mother.
option_2: He asked me how my mother is.
option_3: He said to me how your mother was.
option_4: He asked me how my mother was.
description:
Direct

Indirect

Interrogative

Assertive

Present Tense

(is/are/am)

Past Tense 

(was/were)

said to (?)

asked

connective

W/H word (how)

your

my (according to Obj. – R.V.)

question: Transform the given sentence into indirect speech: She said to him, “Do you want to take my seat?”
option_1: She asked him if he wanted to take her seat.
option_2: She told him if he wants to take her seat.
option_3: She said him if he had wanted to take her seat.
option_4: She asked him if you want to take seat.
description:
Direct

Indirect

Interrogative

Assertive

Simple Present Tense [V1/V5(s/es)]

Simple Past Tense (V2)

said to (?)

asked

connective

if

you

he (according to Obj. – R.V.)

my

her (according to Sub. – R.V.)

question: Transform the given sentence into indirect speech: I said to my mother, “I will certainly take you to Bengaluru this week.”
option_1: I told my mother he would certainly take her to Bengaluru that week.
option_2: I told my mother that I would certainly take her to Bengaluru that week.
option_3: I told my mother she would certainly take her to Bengaluru that week.
option_4: I told my mother that I would certainly take her to Bengaluru this week.
description:
Direct

Indirect

said to

told

connective

that

will/shall

would

you

her (according to Obj. – R.V.)

this

that

question: Transform the given sentence into indirect speech: Mother says, “Shona dances on the stage.”
option_1: Mother says that Shona dances on the stage.
option_2: Mother says that Shona danced on the stage.
option_3: Mother said that Shona dances on the stage.
option_4: Mother tells that Shona danced on the stage.
description: -If the reported verb is given in present or future tense, the tense of the reported speech will not be changed.

question: Choose the option in which Narration in the given sentence has been correctly changed: Hari said, “Tina, why are you crying?”
option_1: Hari asked Tina why was she crying?
option_2: Hari asked Tina why she was crying?
option_3: Hari asked Tina why she was crying.
option_4: Hari advised Tina that she should not cry.
description:
Direct

Indirect

Interrogative

Assertive

Present Continuous Tense (is/are/am + V1 + ing)

Past Continuous Tense (was/were + V1 + ing)

said (?)

asked

connective

W/H word (why)

you

she (according to Obj. – R.V.)

question: Choose the appropriate indirect statement of the given sentence: He said, “Let us wait for the award.”
option_1: He proposed that they should wait for the award.
option_2: He proposed that we should be waiting for the award.
option_3: He proposed to wait for the award.
option_4: He requested them that they should be waiting for the award.
description:
Imperative Sentence:

Direct

Indirect

said

proposed

connective

that

Let us + V1

they should + V1

question: Transform the given sentence into indirect speech: The principal said to him, “Why did you not attend the assembly yesterday?”
option_1: The principal told him why he did not attend the assembly the previous day.
option_2: The principal asked him why he had not attended the assembly the previous day.
option_3: The principal said him why he had not attended the assembly yesterday.
option_4: The principal asks him why he had not attended the assembly the previous day.
description:
Direct

Indirect

Interrogative

Assertive

Simple Past Tense (V2)

Past Perfect Tense (had + V3)

said to (?)

asked

connective

W/H word (why)

you

he (according to Obj. – R.V.)

yesterday

the previous day/ the day before

question: Transform the given sentence into indirect speech: Our father said, “We all live on the Earth.”
option_1: Our father said we all live on the Earth.
option_2: Our father said that we all live on the Earth.
option_3: Our father told that we all live on the Earth.
option_4: Our father said that we all lived on the Earth.
description: -If general truth, universal truth, proverbial sayings, habitual actions, historical facts, mathematical facts, scientific facts etc. are used, the tense of reported speech will not be changed.

question: Transform the given sentence into indirect speech: He said to me. “Don’t push this box.”
option_1: He prohibited me not to pushed that box.
option_2: He prohibited me don’t push that box.
option_3: He prohibited me to push that box.
option_4: He prohibited me to pushes that box.
description:
Imperative Sentence: (Negative)

Direct

Indirect

said to (Don’t)

prohibited

connective

to

this

that

question: Transform the given sentence into indirect speech: He promised, “I will do it tomorrow.”
option_1: He promised that he will do it tomorrow.
option_2: He promised that he will do it the next day.
option_3: He promised that he would do it tomorrow.
option_4: He promised that he would do it the next day.
description:
Direct

Indirect

connective

that

will/shall

would

tomorrow

the next day

I

he (according to Sub. – R.V.)

question: Transform the given sentence into indirect speech: Your friend will say to me, “You are late again.”
option_1: Your friend will say me that you are late again.
option_2: Your friend will ask me that I am late again.
option_3: Your friend will tell me that I am late again.
option_4: Your friend will tell me that you are late again.
description:
Direct

Indirect

say to

tell

connective

that

you

I (according to Obj. – R.V.)

Note: If the reported verb is given in present or future tense, the tense of the reported speech will not be changed.

question: Transform the given sentence into indirect speech: He said, “What a lovely voice she has!”
option_1: He exclaimed that she have been a very lovely voice.
option_2: He exclaimed that she has a very lovely voice.
option_3: He exclaimed that she had lovely voice.
option_4: He exclaimed that she had a very lovely voice.
description:
-Exclamatory Sentence:

Direct

Indirect

has/have (used to show possession in present tense)

had (used to show possession in past tense)

said

exclaimed

connective

that

What!

a very


Note: In exclamatory sentence, before an adjective ‘very’ is used and before a noun ‘great’ is used.

question: Transform the given sentence into indirect speech: The teacher said to the student, “Can you explain this?”
option_1: The teacher asked the student whether he can explain this.
option_2: The teacher asked the student whether he can explain that.
option_3: The teacher asked the student whether he could explain this.
option_4: The teacher asked the student whether he could explain that.
description:
Direct

Indirect

Interrogative

Assertive

said to (?)

asked

connective

whether

Can

could

this

that

question: Transform the given sentence into direct speech: He said that he goes for a walk every morning.
option_1: He said, “I went for a walk every morning.”
option_2: He said, “I go for a walk every morning.“
option_3: He said, “I will go for a walk every morning.”
option_4: He said, “He went for a walk every morning.”
description: -If general truth, universal truth, proverbial sayings, habitual actions, historical facts, mathematical facts, scientific facts etc. are used, the tense of reported speech will not be changed.

question: Transform the given sentence into indirect speech: He said to me, “May you get success in your life!”
option_1: He asked me that you might get success in my life.
option_2: He wished me that I might get success in my life.
option_3: He prayed me that you may get success in your life.
option_4: He told me that I might get success in your life.
description:
Optative sentence:
 

Direct

Indirect

said to

wished

connective

that

May

might

you/your

I/my (according to Obj. – R.V.)

question: Transform the given sentence into indirect speech: “If I have the map, I will go there myself”, said the tourist.
option_1: The tourist said that if he had the map he would go there myself.
option_2: The tourist said that if he had the map he will go there himself.
option_3: The tourist said that if he had the map he will go there myself.
option_4: The tourist said that if he had the map he would go there himself.

Direct

Indirect

said (Obj. is not given)

said

has/have (used to show possession in present tense)

question: Transform the given sentence into indirect speech: Rohit said to Sonu, “Where is the way of the Diksha Library?”

option_2: Rohit asked Sonu where the way of the Diksha Library was.
option_3: Rohit asked Sonu where the way of the Diksha Library has been.
option_4: Rohit asked Sonu where the way of the Diksha Library is.

question: Transform the given sentence into indirect speech: “I have broken the window”, he said.

option_3: He admitted that he had broken the window.
option_4: He admitted to break the window.

option_2: My mother forbade me to park his car in front of the garage.
option_3: My mother forbade me to park her car in front of the garage.
option_4: My mother forbade me to park my car in front of the garage.

question: The idiom ‘Under the weather’ means ____________________.
description:
-Under the weather – to feel ill, unwell. (अस्वस्थ होना)
eg. I'm feeling a bit under the weather. I think I'm getting a cold.

question: Write the correct meaning of the underlined idiom: The news of Rehan’s death spread like wild fire.
description:
-Spread like wild fire – spread with great speed. (जंगल की आग की तरह फैलना)
eg. These stories are spreading like wildfire through the city.

question: Write the correct meaning of the underlined idiom: To be successful in today’s world we require the gift of the gab.
description:
-Gift of the gab – someone who has the ability to speak well. (बोलने की कला में निपुण होना)
eg. She's got the gift of the gab. She should work in sales and marketing.

question: Write the correct meaning of the underlined idiom: Most people live from hand to mouth these days because of inflation.
description:
-Live from hand to mouth – to have just enough money to live on and nothing extra. (किसी प्रकार गुजारा करना)
eg. My father earned very little and there were four kids, so we lived from hand to mouth.

question: Write the correct meaning of the underlined idiom: Some people do not grease anybody's palm on any account.
description:
-Grease someone’s palm – to bribe someone. (रिश्वत देना)
eg. If you want to play for state level matches, be sure to grease the selector’s palm.

question: The idiom ‘Eat like a bird’ means ____________________.
description:
-Eat like a bird – eat very little. (बहुत कम खाना)
eg. Khushboo eats like a bird. I don't know how she stays healthy.
eg. We weep crocodile tears for the worst and damaged, but are basically happy with things as we are.

question: The idiom ‘To have an oily tongue’ means _____________________________.
option_3: to be excessively smooth with words
description:
-To have an oily tongue – to be excessively smooth with words; to be a smooth talker. (शब्द सहज व्यक्ति)
eg. He can become a good salesman as he has an oily tongue.

question: Write the correct meaning of the underlined idiom: Give me your complaint in black and white.
option_1: on a white paper with blank ink
description:
-In black and white – in writing. (लिखित रूप में)
eg. I won't believe it until I see it in black and white.

question: The idiom ‘To smell a rat’ means _____________________________.
option_2: to have reason to know the presence of a rat
option_3: to learn the smell of a rat
option_4: to know the smell of a rat
description:
-To smell a rat – to suspect that something is wrong in a particular situation. (गलत होने का पता लगाना)
eg. They claim they will honor the terms of the contract, but I smell a rat.

question: The idiom ‘In apple pie order’ means _____________________________.
description:
-In apple-pie order – neat and tidy. (सुव्यवस्थित)
eg. My mother is always cleaning. The house is in apple-pie order.

question: The idiom ‘A white elephant’ means _____________________________.
description:
-A white elephant – a possession unwanted by the owner but difficult to dispose of. (एक मूल्यवान सम्पति जिसका रखरखाव महंगा है)
eg. She believes the development may become a white elephant that fails to attract suitable tenants.

question: The idiom ‘A snake in the grass’ means _____________________________.
option_2: presence of many snakes in an area
description:
-A snake in the grass – a deceitful or treacherous person. (एक धोखेबाज या विश्वासघाती व्यक्ति)
eg. My best friend was a kind man when we were in college but now he is like a snake in the grass.

question: The idiom 'A herculean task’ means _____________________________.
option_1: a task which requires little effect
option_3: a task which requires great effort
option_4: a task which does not require danger
description:
-A herculean task – a task requiring huge amounts of physical strength. (बहुत कठिन कार्य)
eg. It took herculean efforts to survive the ordeal of fighting in such inhospitable space.

question: The idiom ‘In a nutshell’ means _____________________________.
description:
-In a nutshell – a brief or short summary of something. (संक्षेप में)
eg. She had summed up his immediate task in a nutshell.

question: Write the correct word to complete the given proverb: Something is better than ____________.
description: -Something is better than nothing – it is better to get only some of what you want than to get nothing at all. (नहीं से कुछ भला)

question: Write the correct word to complete the given proverb: All that glitters is not ___________.
description: -All that glitters is not gold – something might not be as valuable as it seems to be. (चमकने वाली हर चीज़ सोना नहीं होती)

question: Write the correct meaning of the given proverb: Rome was not built in a day
option_1: it takes time to create great things.
option_2: you have to win many wars to build an empire.
option_3: a task done hurriedly fails completely
description: -Rome wasn’t built in a day – it takes a long time to create something complicated or impressive. (हथेली पर दही नहीं जमता; सफलता पाने के लिए जीवन में कड़ी मेहनत करनी पड़ती है)

question: Write the correct meaning of the given proverb: Strike while the iron is hot–
option_1: it is never too late to improve
option_2: make the most of present opportunities
description: -Strike while the iron is hot – to act quickly when an opportunity presents itself. (मौके का लाभ उठाना)

question: Write the correct word to complete the given proverb: A stitch in time saves ___________.
description: -A stitch in time saves nine – it is better to deal with problems immediately than letting them become bigger. (वक्त का एक टाँका बेवक्त के सौ टाँकों से बढकर है)

question: Write the correct word to complete the given proverb: Money doesn’t grow on __________.
description: -Money doesn’t grow on trees – it requires effort to earn money. (पैसे पेड़ पर नहीं उगते)
